awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Niela Project: A Qualitative Investigation of the Experiences of Black Women in Pursuit of Doctorates and Postdoctorates in Engineering and Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
The Niela Project: A Qualitative Investigation of the Experiences of Black Women in Pursuit of Doctorates and Postdoctorates in Engineering and Computing, is a 4-year collaborative research study (conducted by the University of California-Irvine?s Heidelberg College and Engineers for Equity) to explore how Black female doctoral students and postdoctoral scholars succeed in their engineering and computer science programs. Although university administrators are well informed of the graduation disparities for Black women, there are no known models or interventions in place that better serve them. Therefore, the goal of this effort is to improve the understanding of the dynamics and factors that Black women's experiences may have on their academic persistence and overall well-being.
 
Interviews with faculty mentors and other advisors to 125 Black women graduate students and postdoctoral scholars in engineering and computer science will be conducted, along with a qualitative study of a population that has not yet been researched separately from the larger context of women graduate students and postdocs. The aim is to unveil the mentors' understanding of: 1) the women's experiences, 2) the specific challenges the women encounter as the mentors advise Black female doctoral students and postdoctoral scholars, and 3) the key strategies the mentors implemented to help the students persist and nurture their well-being. Additional outcomes of the study include an awareness of the key challenges Black female doctoral students and postdoctoral scholars in Engineering and Computer Science programs face on a daily basis; important ways to enhance their academic persistence; and programmatic changes that could broaden the participation of these students and postdoctoral scholars in Engineering and Computer Science.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
The goal of The Niela Project: A Qualitative Investigation of the Experiences of Black Women in Pursuit of Doctorates and Postdoctorates in Engineering and Computing (referred to as The Niela Project) was to increase the understanding of Black doctoral women’s experiences and how their experiences impacted their academic persistence and overall well-being in computing and engineering. Phase 1 of the project investigated two research questions: 

  • How do Black women pursuing doctoral degrees in engineering and computer science perceive and characterize their experiences while enrolled in their programs? 

  • How do Black women shape their academic persistence and overall well-being? 

Thirty-nine Black graduate women in engineering and computing were recruited through national organizations and conferences, such as the National GEM Consortium, National Society of Blacks in Computing, National Society of Black Engineers, and Tapia Conference, to participate in The Niela Project. These participants were interviewed to learn more about their experiences as a Black doctoral women in engineering and computing programs, challenges they encountered during their doctoral experience, and strategies they used to persist and nurture their well-being. Three prominent themes emerged from the interviews: 


  • Token/The Lone Ranger - Participants reported being “one of a few” Black women. Participants shared they felt highly visible, while also feeling a sense of invisibility due to race and gender. They also stated an increased awareness of race and gender, along with a sense of pressure to challenge stereotypes and be a trailblazer for other Black women.

  • Code-Switching - Participants believed their typical way of interacting or presenting were rarely accepted in the academic setting, so they felt increased pressure to change how they are to conform to the academic or engineering culture in order to feel accepted.

  • Support/Bigger Than Me - Participants found support from a variety of sources, including family, Black student groups, advisors, and professional organizations. They  framed the dissertation process as being “bigger than themselves.” Some participants used their desire to motivate others, serve as a trailblazer, and accomplish their degree for others as a persistence strategy.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, The Niela Project implemented Phase 2 of the project to focus on Black doctoral women experiences during the pandemic. Phase 2 identified three questions to better understand the coping strategies, as well as resiliency strategies Black doctoral women utilized as a way to succeed and thrive in their engineering and computing programs: 

  • How do Black women enrolled in graduate school characterize and perceive their academic experiences while dealing with the effects of COVID-19 and overlapping racial injustices? 

  • What does the institution look like for Black women in an era of a global pandemic and ongoing racial violence?

  • How can power be reimagined to empower students, especially Black women graduate students?

Seventeen participants from Phase 1 participated in the Phase 2 interviews. Outcomes of Phase 2 were consistent with the data collected from the 39 participants in Phase 1. In addition, three new themes emerged: 

  • Lack of a​​ccess to adequate academic advising and mentoring - Some participants shared that they had to navigate as a graduate student on their own because of the absence of their advisor, lack of communication with their advisor, or lack of support and mentorship in their program.   

  • Prioritization of personal wellness - Participants made their wellbeing a priority. During the pandemic, they participated in daily self-care activities, maintained and strengthened their spirituality, developed stress-management techniques, and utilized counseling and psychological services. 

  • Strategies to support Black graduate women - Participants provided examples of the type of support that had or would have liked to have had to aid them during the pandemic. These include meaningful and intentional advising and mentorship; community building and career development opportunities that meet the needs of women of color; cultural competency training for students, faculty, and staff; space to increase awareness about the experiences the Black community face; and enhanced faculty, department, and student accountability. 

Outcomes of The Niela Project allowed Black doctoral women in engineering and computing to share their experiences providing an opportunity for educators and researchers to learn more about the lived racialized and gendered experiences of Black women in doctoral programs. Both phases of the project identified specific challenges Black women pursuing doctoral degrees in engineering and computing encounter and strategies they use to thrive in their academic professions. This project also explored how the participants adjusted during the pandemic. Results of this project can be used to improve engineering and computing graduate programs, policies, and strategies for more inclusive educational experiences.


Last Modified: 12/22/2023
Modified by: Marjorie C Shavers

Phase 1 of the project investigated two research questions:

How do Black women shape their academic persistence and overall well-being?




Thirty-nine Black graduate women in engineering and computing were recruited through national organizations and conferences, such as the National GEM Consortium, National Society of Blacks in Computing, National Society of Black Engineers, and Tapia Conference, to participate in The Niela Project. They also stated an increased awareness of race and gender, along with a sense of pressure to challenge stereotypes and be a trailblazer for other Black women.




Code-Switching - Participants believed their typical way of interacting or presenting were rarely accepted in the academic setting, so they felt increased pressure to change how they are to conform to the academic or engineering culture in order to feel accepted.




Support/Bigger Than Me - Participants found support from a variety of sources, including family, Black student groups, advisors, and professional organizations. They framed the dissertation process as being bigger than themselves. Some participants used their desire to motivate others, serve as a trailblazer, and accomplish their degree for others as a persistence strategy.

Seventeen participants from Phase 1 participated in the Phase 2 interviews. Outcomes of Phase 2 were consistent with the data collected from the 39 participants in Phase 1. In addition, three new themes emerged:




Lack of a​​ccess to adequate academic advising and mentoring - Some participants shared that they had to navigate as a graduate student on their own because of the absence of their advisor, lack of communication with their advisor, or lack of support and mentorship in their program.

Strategies to support Black graduate women - Participants provided examples of the type of support that had or would have liked to have had to aid them during the pandemic. These include meaningful and intentional advising and mentorship; community building and career development opportunities that meet the needs of women of color; cultural competency training for students, faculty, and staff; space to increase awareness about the experiences the Black community face; and enhanced faculty, department, and student accountability.

Both phases of the project identified specific challenges Black women pursuing doctoral degrees in engineering and computing encounter and strategies they use to thrive in their academic professions. This project also explored how the participants adjusted during the pandemic. Results of this project can be used to improve engineering and computing graduate programs, policies, and strategies for more inclusive educational experiences.
